---
title: '‘Who is More Scorn’d than a Poor Scholar Is?’: Academic Precarity and the
  Early Modern Theatre'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-RQQD87IB" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-RQQD87IB" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Williamson's journal paper examines the play "Patient Grissil" from 1603 to explore the challenges faced by scholars in early modern England and today. The study highlights the character Laureo, who is portrayed as both a flatterer and a rebel, reflecting the precarious situation of scholars during a time when there were more graduates than available jobs. Williamson connects this historical context to modern times, questioning how unstable job conditions affect scholars' ability to critique society. The paper suggests that today's critics might share similarities with Laureo, as they navigate the balance between job security and the freedom to challenge norms. This study is relevant for understanding the ongoing struggles of academics in finding stable employment and voicing dissent.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-RQQD87IB" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Academic Precarity, Early Modern Theatre, Scholarly Representation, Historical Context, Radical Critique
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-RQQD87IB" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This piece explores Dekker, Chettle and Haughton’s Patient Grissil (1603), as a means to think through the nature of scholarly precarity in both early modern England and the world today. It focuses, in particular, on the representation of the scholar Laureo, a marginal character defined by both sycophancy and sedition. Patient Grissil is situated in the specific circumstances of late sixteenth century England, a time in which the number of graduates far exceeded the number of professional positions available. But the piece also seeks to place its historicist reading in conversation with our own historical moment. What is the nature of the connections between precarity, material stability and radical critique – and to what extent might the modern critic be considered the counterpart to the malcontent Laureo?
  </article>
